text: Hey folks! :wave: We're looking at switching up our content stack and moving away from Ghost. Would love to hear how some of y'all are running/hosting content at your organizations. Probably going to steer clear of Wordpress, and our main site is on Webflow, but I'm not sure that that will work for our blog use case for very long. Especially interested in hearing from folks in the Contentful realm.

elements.text: Hey folks!

We're looking at switching up our content stack and moving away from Ghost. Would love to hear how some of y'all are running/hosting content at your organizations. Probably going to steer clear of Wordpress, and our main site is on Webflow, but I'm not sure that that will work for our blog use case for very long. Especially interested in hearing from folks in the Contentful realm.

text:
What is your "blog use case?"

Webflow has a pretty solid API that can be hooked into a headless CMS system. Although there do appear to be some limitations with styling the rich text itself inside the dynamic CMS on Webflow.

elements.text:
What is your "blog use case?"

text:
I'm used to seeing so many companies moving to Ghost and not away from it. Is there a specific reason you're migrating?

I personally haven't used Contentful, but I'm going to ask my clients who do use it and get their feedback on it

text: It takes me an hour to write a creative brief for an article. Is that crazy?

elements.text: It takes me an hour to write a creative brief for an article. Is that crazy?

text: Do you use templates? Might speed up the process

elements.text: Do you use templates? Might speed up the process

text: About the same for me. I use templates and I use an AI tool to help with research, but in the end, it takes me that long to put it all together, making sure I think it through carefully.

elements.text: About the same for me. I use templates and I use an AI tool to help with research, but in the end, it takes me that long to put it all together, making sure I think it through carefully.

text: I'm not a writer but I take over an hour for SEO research per article (often but not always), separate from the creative :man-shrugging:

elements.text: I'm not a writer but I take over an hour for SEO research per article (often but not always), separate from the creative

text: If you're doing everything manually, then I could see why it takes an hour. When we switched to Topic, it cut down our content brief generation time to about 20-25 minutes

elements.text: If you're doing everything manually, then I could see why it takes an hour. When we switched to Topic, it cut down our content brief generation time to about 20-25 minutes

text: Majority of teams we talk to at Content Harmony are in the 1-2 hour range building the briefs manually. Our goal is to get them into the 10-30 minute range once they’re on our workflow, but a lot still depends on how deep you go into the outline, and how much subject matter expertise you have on the topic.

elements.text: Majority of teams we talk to at Content Harmony are in the 1-2 hour range building the briefs manually. Our goal is to get them into the 10-30 minute range once they’re on our workflow, but a lot still depends on how deep you go into the outline, and how much subject matter expertise you have on the topic.

text: I think it ultimately depends on what you want to do—an hour for putting on your thinking cap, doing some research, refining an initial idea, verifying your sources, and turning all of this into a solid outline that will lead to a convincing, opinionated piece seems like an _extremely reasonable amount of time_ to me :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I think it ultimately depends on what you want to do—an hour for putting on your thinking cap, doing some research, refining an initial idea, verifying your sources, and turning all of this into a solid outline that will lead to a convincing, opinionated piece seems like an
extremely reasonable amount of time
to me

text: <@U01AU94TABA> Templates? Yes and no. I use Frase a lot & then kinda format it in my usual way. But if you asked me for a template, I would send you an example of a previous brief

elements.text: Templates? Yes and no. I use Frase a lot & then kinda format it in my usual way. But if you asked me for a template, I would send you an example of a previous brief

text:
To Fio's point - I think more time is OK sometimes, particularly if (A) you don't have many briefs to do or (B) you are the writer and that research time makes the piece better.

But as soon as you're doing more than a few briefs per week, passing them off to multiple writers, or you're duplicating too much work from what the writer is going to do as well, that's when I think speeding up the process and teaching the writer when to override the brief becomes important.

elements.text:
To Fio's point - I think more time is OK sometimes, particularly if (A) you don't have many briefs to do or (B) you are the writer and that research time makes the piece better.

But as soon as you're doing more than a few briefs per week, passing them off to multiple writers, or you're duplicating too much work from what the writer is going to do as well, that's when I think speeding up the process and teaching the writer when to override the brief becomes important.

text: If you are taking an hour means that you care for it. So there is nothing wrong. It is always better to gather at much information at the beginning to feed your creative juices later while writing. And indeed, that's the norm for serious content marketing folks, so you are right up there. So give yourself a pat on your back.

text: Curious about this too. We’ve been Hubspot in the beginning, then migrated to Ghost. What are your reasons for moving away from Ghost?

elements.text: Curious about this too. We’ve been Hubspot in the beginning, then migrated to Ghost. What are your reasons for moving away from Ghost?

text:
Same here, about an hour. Also depends who I’m writing the brief for (inhouse writer or external), and what kind of content (a quick _X best way to ____ takes 20 minutes, an in-depth guide with a more complex structure a good hour). Breakdown:
• 40% SEO work (incl looking at what’s already out there)
• 20% how can we create something remarkable vs “just another slightly better version of what’s already out there”
• 30% how this relates to our existing content library and/or product 
• 10% closing all the tabs I opened, plus dealing with self hatred and anxiety :laughing:

elements.text: Same here, about an hour. Also depends who I’m writing the brief for (inhouse writer or external), and what kind of content (a quick
X best way to ___
takes 20 minutes, an in-depth guide with a more complex structure a good hour). Breakdown:

30% how this relates to our existing content library and/or product
